comments:
I noticed the following in my log when I shutdown with the help browser open.  
Likely code still running after the help plugin has been stopped.

I'll give you my opinion after I see the proposed fix :-).

Calling close() methods on browsers adapters contrubuted through extentsions 
is dangerous until proper listening of this extenstion point is implemented 
(it was not considered important for 3.0), so it should be avoided.  The 
browsers from plug-ins that are deactivated shoould ensure they are closed 
anyway, and not rely on close() being called at shut down of help system.

It turns out that embedded browser now has the problem because it is the only 
one that actually has implementation of the close() method.  All other browser 
adapters have a noop close().  The close() method from the embedded browser 
does not need to be called by the help system since in this release the 
embedded browser runs in-process so disposing of display by the workbench or 
stand-alone help already takes care of disposing of embedded browser.


The proposed fix is to remove call to a methods that loops and executes close
() on all the browsers during org.eclipse.help.base plug-in shutdown - 
commenting out one line:


Index: src/org/eclipse/help/internal/base/BaseHelpSystem.java
===================================================================
RCS 
file: /home/eclipse/org.eclipse.help.base/src/org/eclipse/help/internal/base/Ba
seHelpSystem.java,v
retrieving revision 1.19
diff -u -r1.19 BaseHelpSystem.java
--- src/org/eclipse/help/internal/base/BaseHelpSystem.java	22 May 2004 
11:19:21 -0000	1.19
+++ src/org/eclipse/help/internal/base/BaseHelpSystem.java	22 Jun 2004 
21:03:04 -0000
@@ -117,7 +117,7 @@
 			System.out.println("Base Help System is shutting 
down."); //$NON-NLS-1$
 		}
 		// close any browsers created
-		BrowserManager.getInstance().closeAll();
+		//BrowserManager.getInstance().closeAll();
 
 		if (getInstance().searchManager != null) {
 			getInstance().searchManager.close();

The only problem would be if someone contributes a browser adapter that opens 
a shell, etc. which does have to be closed.

How realistic this is for 3.0? Did anybody contributed browser adapters in the 
past?
Of course, the question should read 'did anybody contribute' :-).

If it does have to be close, it is up to the plug-in to ensure their resources 
are implicitly (by correct parenting) or explicitly disposed, which would 
close the browser.

Calling close() by help at shutdown is always wrong, since the contributed 
browser (I do not think there is any) is disposed before org.eclipse.help.base 
plug-in.

Also the API specs do not make any promises that close() method would ever be 
called.

The close() method is still useful.  It can still be called to shut down the 
browser when it is not needed and a new one is opened in its place, but not 
necessary at shutdown.

There was one contributed back to eclipse (for Mac).

I agree with the fix proposed.
+1

The browser adapter for Mac is a one (long) liner that does not implement close
().
I am looking for more votes.  Thanks.

Even if the display got recreated, I find the stack trace here to be unexpected.
SWT should not fail within a dispose.  This may indicate another problem in SWT.
Steve?

Nick,

There are three stack traces here.  The first two are not caused by help, but 
they affect what happens later and uncovered problem in help.

When first two traces do not happen, help creates a new Display, does not 
displose of it and shutdowns normally.   SWT does not have problems there, 
therefore the problem was not noticed for a long time.

When first two traces somehow happen, help does not create a new Display but a 
new Runnable in an already shutdown plug-in.

These - calling shut down plug-in and attempting new Display or new Runnable 
is what this bug is about.
The first two stacks are already reported in bug 67660 
https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=67660

traces.message: The  class "org.eclipse.help.ui.internal.browser.embedded.EmbeddedBrowserAdapter$2"  cannot be loaded because the system is shutting down and the plug- in "org.eclipse.help.ui" has already been stopped.
